column2: the result of this inquiry seems to be
column3: that Past Masters have no inherent right
column5: to a seat in the Grand Lodge; but as every Grand Lodge has the power
column7: to make regulations for its own government
column8: it may or may not admit them to membership
column9: according to its own notion of expediency.Some of the Grand Lodges have not only disfranchised Past Masters but Wardens also
column10: and restricted membership only to acting Masters. This innovation has arisen from the fact that the payment of mileage and expenses to three representative would entail a heavy burden on the revenue of the Grand Lodge. The reason may have been imperative; but in the practice
column11: pecuniary expediency has been made to override an ancient usage.In determining
column13: who are the constitutional members of a Grand Lodge
column14: deriving their membership from inherent right
column15: I should say that they are the Masters and Wardens of all regular lodges in the jurisdiction
column16: with the Grand Officers chosen by them. All others
column17: who by local regulations are made members
column19: and not by prescription or ancient law.
